Headline.Para: Photos: A Family Heirloom Marks 100 Years; Carol Hein and her husband Scott treasure the 1918 Buick passed down from her grandparents and parents.

Snippet.Para: Carol and Scott Hein of Prescott, Ariz., with their 1918 Buick. According to Ms. Hein, this Buick spent 43 years in storage (from 1937 to 1980). 'But it was never forgotten,' she says. Her parents restored it.

Headline.Para: Photos: A Family Heirloom Marks 100 Years; Carol Hein and her husband Scott treasure the 1918 Buick passed down from her grandparents and parents.

LeadPara.Para: Carol and Scott Hein of Prescott, Ariz., with their 1918 Buick. According to Ms. Hein, this Buick spent 43 years in storage (from 1937 to 1980). 'But it was never forgotten,' she says. Her parents restored it.
According to the brand's official website, Buick first incorporated in 1903, in Flint, Mich. Buick cars are still built today by General Motors.

TailParas.Para: The 1918 Montana license plate is not original. 'This is a commemorative plate I found at a car show,' says Ms. Hein. 'I liked that it was blue, because Montana is called "Big Sky Country".'
The Buick's hood ornament is original and also serves as the car's radiator cap and temperature gauge (a thermometer is built in).
On the rear of the car is the official Arizona 'Historic Vehicle' plate, and the spare tire.
The year this Buick was built, the company was also building aviation engines for America's war effort in World War I.
According to Ms. Hein, the wooden spoked wheels are original and were carefully restored.
The Heins have shown the Buick at many car shows. 'It is racking up ribbons,' says Ms. Hein.
'My husband Scott is a pilot and he usually drives it,' Ms. Hein says of her outings in the Buick. 'I get nervous. If I screw up, where will I find the parts to fix it?'
Some detail of the car's restored interior.

A close-up of the speedometer and the odometer. The speedometer works, says Ms. Hein, but she doesn't know how accurate it is. 'Believe me,' she says, 'we don't have to worry about exceeding the speed limit.'
The Heins out on the road. 'When we are in it,' Ms. Hein says, 'I feel the presence of my grandparents and my parents. It truly is the family vehicle.'
A shot of the car's inline four-cylinder engine.
The year this vehicle was built, a Hartford Courant journalist wrote, 'This car, so well-known all over the United Statesâ€”has shown by its record that its success is well-deserved.'
